questions.text:
Given below is a list of equipment used for the cold storage of vaccines. Arrange the cold storage equipment in the correct order of usage, starting from the primary health center level to the national level.
  1. Walk-in-Freezers
  2. Walk-in-coolers
  3. Deep freezer
  4. Ice lined refrigerators
questions.solution:
The cold chain equipments that are used at various healthcare strata starting from the primary health center to the national level are 4-3-2-1 i.e. ice lined refrigerators → deep freezer → walk-in-coolers → walk-in-freezers.

Ice-lined refrigerators (ILRs) are similar to conventional refrigerators and are lined with ice packs or tubes. They are categorized based on the vaccine storage capacity. Smaller ones are supplied to the primary health center (PHC) headquarters, while larger ones are supplied to district headquarters. They maintain a temperature of 2-8° Celsius for the storage of vaccines. They have different temperature zones for different vaccines and they are stored accordingly in the baskets that are provided in most ILRs.

Deep freezer (DF) is also similar to a conventional refrigerator but has a top-opening lid. It maintains a temperature of -15° to -25° celsius. It is used at the district level and above for the storage of oral polio vaccines for 3 months. At the sub-district level, it is used for freezing icepacks.

Walk-in-coolers (WIC) are insulated cold rooms with two cooling units with an uninterrupted power supply. They maintain a temperature of 2-8° celsius. They are used at government medical store depots, state, regional, and occasionally district level vaccine stores. 

Walk-in-freezers (WIF) are similar to WIC but maintain a temperature of -15° to -25° celsius. They are used at national, state, and regional vaccine stores.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: Which of the following variables is measured on the nominal scale?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the A, B, O blood groups can be measured on a nominal scale.

Data will always fall into one of the following four scales:

  • Nominal
  • Ordinal
  • Interval
  • Ratio

Nominal scale data can be divided into qualitative categories or groups. Examples include male/female, black/white, or red/green. No order or ratio from the data is implied. Nominal data that falls exclusively into two groups is known as dichotomous data. A, B, O blood groups can be clearly divided into qualitative groups and hence can be measured on a nominal scale.

Ordinal scale data holds meaning when it is placed in a particular order. An example is the ranking of students in a class. But, there is no information about the interval size. This means that the difference between the marks of the first and second students may or may not be the same as the difference between the second and third. An example is the Glasgow coma scale and Child-Pugh score.

Interval scale data is similar to ordinal data because it can be placed in a meaningful order. Additionally, they have meaningful intervals between the items, usually measurable quantities. For example, the difference between 100° and 90° is the same as that between 50° and 40° on the temperature scale. But these scales do not have absolute zeroes, which makes ratios between the items meaningless. 

Ratio scale data have similar properties to interval scale data. In addition, they have an absolute zero. Most biomedical variables can be measured on a ratio scale. Examples are weight in pounds or grams, pulse rate in beats/minute, and blood pressure in millimeters of mercury. A pulse rate of 0 indicates a lack of pulse, and a rate of 120/minute is twice as fast as a rate of 60/minute. This means it is possible to calculate meaningful ratios. 

Other options:

Option B: Glasgow coma scale can be measured on the ordinal scale.

Option C: Intelligence quotient can be measured on the interval scale.

Option D: Respiratory rate can be measured with the ratio scale.

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text: According to biomedical waste management protocols, which of the following colored bins should the instrument shown below be discarded in?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dynamic hip screw and it should be discarded in the blue colored bin.

All metallic body implants except metallic sharps are discarded in the blue bin. Metallic sharps (scalpels, blades, needles, etc) are discarded in white or translucent bins.

Other options:

Option A: White (translucent) containers are puncture-proof and leakproof. It is used for the disposal of waste sharps including metals.

Option C: Yellow containers are lined with yellow non-chlorinated plastic bags. It is used for the disposal of anatomical wastes, discarded medicines, and clinical laboratory waste.

Option D: Red containers are lined with red non-chlorinated bags. Recyclable contaminated waste such as intravenous tubes, catheters, and urine bags are discarded in these containers. 

The following image shows the various logos signifying specific types of wastes.

questions.text:
Which of the following are methods of indirect transmission of communicable diseases?
  1. Contact with soil
  2. Droplet nuclei
  3. Fomite borne
  4. Unclean hands and fingers
  5. Transplacental
questions.solution:
Among the given options, droplet nuclei, fomite borne and transmission through unclean hands and fingers are modes of indirect transmission of diseases.

Communicable diseases are classified based on the mode of transmission:

  • Direct:
    • Direct contact (Eg: sexual intercourse)
    • Contact with soil
    • Droplet infection
    • Skin or mucosal inoculation
    • Transplacental 
  • Indirect: 
    • Vehicle-borne
    • Vector-borne
    • Air-borne
      • Droplet nuclei
      • Dust
    • Fomite-borne
    • Unclean hands and fingers

The traditional 5 F's - flies, fingers, fomites, food, and fluids can be used to remember the modes of indirect transmission. Some infectious agents are able to survive in the external environment while maintaining their basic properties of virulence. This is a  requirement for this indirect transmission. 

An important distinction has to be drawn between droplet nuclei infection and droplet infection. The main difference between airborne droplet nuclei and droplet transmission is in the size of infected/contagious particles and whether proximity is required for transmission.

Droplet nuclei/residue from evaporated droplets containing infective microorganisms can result in airborne transmission. The size of these droplet nuclei is <5 μm in diameter, and they can remain suspended in the air for significant periods of time, allowing them to be transmitted over distances >1 m.  There's no need for close proximity or contact. Diseases like chickenpox, measles, tuberculosis, and influenza can spread through airborne transmission.

Droplet transmission occurs when one coughs or sneezes, and contagious droplets from the infected person travel shortly in the air and directly comes in contact with another person's conjunctiva, mouth, or nasal mucosa. The particle size here is >5 μm in diameter. Transmission here requires close proximity and direct contact. Examples of diseases spread via this route include the common cold, diphtheria, and whooping cough.

Related Pearl: Modes of Transmission of Communicable Diseases

Direct

Indirect

Direct contact

Droplet infection

Contact with soil

Inoculation into skin or mucosa

Vertical (transplacental)

Vehicle-borne

Vector borne – mechanical or biological

Air borne – droplet nuclei or dust

Fomite borne

Unclean hands and finger

questions.text: A statistician is working on a study about the hemoglobin status of children in an area. He plotted the frequency distribution as shown below.  Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively of the same?
questions.solution:
The image given shows a positively/ right-skewed distribution where mean> median> mode. Hence, the mean, median, and mode must be 11, 9, and 7 respectively. None of the other options have such a sequence.

The observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency is known as the mode. If there are two values that occur with the same greatest frequency, the distribution is bimodal. If there are more than two such values, the distribution becomes multimodal. 

When all the values are listed in order, the value that divides the distribution in half is known as the median. When there are an even number of values, the median is obtained by calculating the mean of the two middle scores.

The mean (average) is obtained by summing up all the values and dividing the obtained sum by the total number of values in the distribution.

Skewed distributions are the ones that have asymmetric frequency distributions. They can be identified as positive (right) or negative (left) according to the location of the tail of the curve.

In the image, the tail is located on the positive side of the graph (right side) and so it is a positively or right-skewed distribution. A positively skewed data set contains a large number of low scores but a small number of very high scores. It is vice versa in negatively skewed distributions.

The mean in a positively skewed distribution is pulled up because of the relatively small number of very high scores. The mode is the most frequent and the highest point on the curve, while the median lies between the mean and mode. 

Other options:

Option A: Mean= median= mode is seen in a normal (unimodal) distribution.

Option C: Mean< median< mode is seen in a negatively skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

questions.text: A mother brought her 18-month-old child for a routine checkup to the sub-center.  According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme, what is the dosage and frequency of iron and folic acid supplementation in this child?

choices.text: 10 mg iron and 200 mcg folic acid, weekly
10 mg iron and 200 mcg folic acid, biweekly
20 mg iron and 100 mcg folic acid, weekly
20 mg iron and 100 mcg folic acid, biweekly

questions.solution:
According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme, 20 mg of iron and 100 mcg of folic acid are given biweekly to an 18-month-old child.

Prophylactic iron should be withheld in cases of acute illness such as diarrhea and pneumonia. It is also not recommended in known cases of thalassemia major or a history of repeated blood transfusions.

Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme follows a 6x6x6 strategy. Here, 6 groups of beneficiaries are assisted by 6 interventions and 6 institutional mechanisms.

The six distinct groups of beneficiaries are children of 6-59 months of age, children of 5-9 years, adolescents, women in the reproductive age group, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. 

The six interventions are:

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation prophylactically
  • Deworming
  • Behavior change communication campaign
  • Using digital methods and point of care treatment
  • Provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Related Pearl: Causes of Iron Deficiency Anemia

Dietary lack

  • Infants, who are at high risk due to the very small amounts of iron in milk. Human breast milk provides only about 0.3 mg/L of iron.
  • The impoverished, who can have suboptimal diets for socioeconomic reasons at any age
  • Older adults, who often have restricted diets with little meat because of limited income or poor dentition
  • Teenagers, who subsist on junk food

Impaired absorption

  • Sprue
  • Gastrectomy (Billroth II surgery)

Increased requirement

  • Growing infants, children, and adolescents
  • Premenopausal women, particularly during pregnancy.
  • Economically deprived women having multiple, closely spaced pregnancies are at exceptionally high risk.

Chronic blood loss

  • Menorrhagia
  • Carcinoma of the cecum
  • Hookworm infestation

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the U-PHC, requesting maternal health and family welfare advice for her daughter-in-law. Which of the following maternal health and family welfare services cannot be given in a U-PHC?

U-PHC: Urban primary health center

OCP: Oral contraceptive pills

IUD: Intrauterine device
questions.solution:
Sterilization services cannot be provided in an urban primary health center. 

The national urban health mission (NUHM) was implemented to improve the urban population's health status, particularly slum dwellers and other vulnerable sections of society. It aims to facilitate their access to quality health care. NUHM aims to cover all urban areas with a population >50,000.

The services provided by the NUHM are delivered through the following:

  • Urban primary health centers (U-PHCs)
  • Urban community health centers (U-CHCs).
  • Outreach services 

Urban primary health centers are set up for every 50,000 people. U-PHC can be located within, or near a slum catering to a slum population of approximately 25,000-30,000. Outpatient services will be available. In areas of high population density, a U-PHC can be set up for a population of 75,000 as well. The U-PHC is predominantly for simple consultations such as the distribution of OCP (oral contraceptive pills)/ CC (combined contraceptives), IUD (intrauterine device) insertion, referral for sterilization, and postnatal care. 

Urban community health centers are set up for every 4-5 U-PHCs or 2,50,000 people. It functions as a referral unit. It would provide in-patient services and would be a 30-50 bedded facility. In metro cities, U-CHCs may be established for every 5 lakh population with 100 beds. The U-CHC provides medical care and does minor surgeries such as sterilization.

The outreach services are targeted at specific groups such as slum dwellers and other vulnerable groups. It will be provided by female health workers, especially ANMs (auxiliary nursing midwifery). They undergo induction training of three to six months and will be then placed at the U-PHCs. On designated days, they move to their respective areas for outreach services. They provide services such as distribution of OCPs, counseling, and follow-up of contraceptive-related complications.

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

  • HWC-PHCs: Population of 30000 in plains, 20000 in hilly/tribal areas
  • Urban HWC-PHCs: Population of 50000
  • Specialist UPHC/Polyclinic (urban): Population of 2.5- 3 lakh

PHC’s and UPHC’s can be further extended to 24X7 PHC’s/UPHC’s

Bed distribution:

questions.text:
Match the following patients with the corresponding healthcare programs that can suitably cater to some aspect of their needs.

Column I

  1. An adolescent girl who is menstruating and requires suvidha sanitary napkins
  2. A pregnant woman in her 2nd trimester needing antenatal care service
  3. A poor elderly male destitute requiring a coronary artery bypass graft
  4. A woman requiring a cesarean section who has to be transferred to a higher center

Column II

a. Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram

b. Pradhan Mantri Rashtriya Janaushadhi Pariyojana

c. Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan

d. Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 1- b, 2- c, 3- d, and 4- a.

An adolescent girl who is menstruating and requires suvidha sanitary napkins - Pradhan Mantri Rashtriya Janaushadhi Pariyojana 

A pregnant woman in her 2nd trimester needing antenatal care service - Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan

A poor elderly male destitute requiring a coronary artery bypass graft  - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana 

A woman requiring a cesarean section who has to be transferred to a higher center - Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram 

The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram has provisions for free transport from home to the health institutions, between facilities in case of referral, and back home from the health institution. These provisions are for pregnant women and sick infants till 30 days after birth. Other services include free treatment, free drugs and consumables, and free delivery including cesarean section.

The Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA) ensures quality antenatal care service. With this, a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic. This happens on the 9th of every month.

The Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana was launched on the 23rd of September 2018. 

  • The government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • More than 10.74 crore poor and vulnerable families (approximately 50 crore beneficiaries) are covered across the country.
  • Cashless access to quality health care services.
  • Primitive tribal groups, destitute, and households without shelters are automatically included.

Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana provides 'suvidha', a 100% biodegradable sanitary napkin for Rs.1 per pad in over 6300 Janaushadhi Kendras for the underprivileged women of India.

questions.text: According to the national framework for malaria elimination in India, states were categorized based on ______.
questions.solution:
The annual parasite index (API) is used to categorize states/union territories under the national framework for malaria elimination in India.

The national framework for malaria elimination in India was launched in February 2016 with the following goals:

  • Eliminate malaria throughout the entire country by 2030
  • Maintain malaria-free status in areas where transmission has been interrupted and prevent re-introduction

It uses the annual parasite index to classify states/union territories into four categories.

  • Category 0 (Prevention of re-establishment phase): States/union territories with zero cases
  • Category 1 (Elimination phase): States/union territories with all their districts having API <1
  • Category 2 (pre-elimination phase): States/union territories with API <1, but some of their districts having API≥1
  • Category 3 (Intensified control phase): States/union territories with API≥1

API is calculated by the formula: confirmed cases during one year X 1000 / population under surveillance.

Regions with API≥ 2 are considered as high-risk areas and are eligible for vector control.

Other options:

Option B: Slide positivity rate is used to describe the percentage of slides positive for the malarial parasite. The type of species is not taken into account.

Option C: Slide falciparum rate is the percentage of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum species. 

Option D: Annual blood examination rate is derived by the formula - number of slides examined X 100/ Population. It is considered an index of operational efficiency.

 

 

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in order of the demographic cycle.

1. Early expanding population

2. Declining population 

3. Low stationary population 

4. Late expanding population

5. High stationary population
questions.solution:
The correct order according to the demographic cycle is high stationary population (5) --> early expanding population  (1) --> late expanding population (4) --> low stationary population (3) --> contracting population  (2).

The demographic cycle has 5 stages:

  • Stage 1: High stationary population 
  • Stage 2: Early expanding population 
  • Stage 3: Late expanding population 
  • Stage 4: Low stationary population 
  • Stage 5: Contracting population

In a high stationary population, there is a high birth rate and a high death rate that cancel each other and the population remains stationary.

The early expanding population is marked by a decline in the death rate but the birth rate stays constant. Many countries in South Asia and Africa are in this phase. 

In the late expanding population there is a further fall in the death rate, with the birth rate beginning to fall. The population is still increasing due to a net increase in births. India has entered this phase. 

A low stationary population is characterized by low birth and low death rate, and this can result in a stationary population. It has occurred in most industrialized countries as a demographic transition shifting from high birth and high death rates to low birth and low death rates.

A declining population is one where the birth rate is lower than the death rate, causing population decline. Examples include East European countries like Germany and Hungary.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: An epidemiologist plans to conduct a prospective study instead of a retrospective study. Which of the following disadvantages does he aim to eliminate by conducting this study?
questions.solution:
Recall bias can be eliminated in a prospective study.

Recall bias is also called memory bias. It is widely seen in retrospective (case-control) studies as extensive history is taken from the participants.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: You are a medical officer evaluating the community health meal programs in your area. One of the program's objectives is to attract more children to maintain attendance in school. Which one of the following statements about this meal program is correct?

choices.text: Provides 1/3rd of daily energy requirement and 1/2 of daily protein requirement
It should be a substitute to the home diet
The menu should not be changed to maintain consistency
The meal should not be prepared in schools

questions.solution:
It provides 1/3rd of daily energy requirement and 1/2 of daily protein requirement is the correct statement about the mid-day meal program

The mid-day meal program (MDMP)/ school lunch program is catered to provide meals for school children. It is offered to school children in an effort to persuade more children to enroll in schools thereby improving children's literacy. It aims to maintain attendance in schools. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the minimum needs program. It is run by the ministry of education.

The meal provided under the MDMP should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets. It must cover at least 1/2 of the total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of the total daily energy requirement for children in schools. The cost of meals should be reasonably low. The meal should be easy to cook in schools. Locally available foods must be used whenever possible. The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.

The mid-day meal scheme functions under the ministry of human resources development as a centrally sponsored scheme. Under this, a cooked mid-day meal with at least 300 calories and 8-12 grams of protein is provided to all children of classes I-V.

questions.text:
Match the objective of each phase of a clinical trial with the phase.

    Column I                                                                               

  1. Indications are finalized and guidelines formulated                
  2. Drug interactions and long-term adverse effects assessed     
  3. Efficacy and dose-ranging are determined                               
  4. Assessment of safety and tolerability

    Column II

    A. Phase I

    B. Phase II

    C. Phase III

    D. Phase IV
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1- C, 2-D, 3-B, and 4-A.

The phases of a clinical trial and their objectives are as given below.

Phase 1 (first in humans) is carried out in 10-100 participants. It aims to test the safety and tolerability of the drug. Usually, healthy volunteers are chosen. Sometimes patients with an advanced or rare disease are also considered. It generally lasts for 1-2 years.

Phase 2 (first in patients) checks the efficacy and dose-ranging of the drug. 50-500 patient subjects receive the experimental drug. It lasts for 2-3 years.

Phase 3 (multisite trial) is carried out for confirmation of the efficacy tested in phase 2. The indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. A few hundred to a few thousand patient subjects receive the drug. It lasts for around 3-5 years.

Phase 4 (postmarketing surveillance) tests for adverse effects, or those that occur only after long-term use and drug interactions. It is done in patients already on treatment with the approved drug. There is no fixed duration for this stage.  

Related Pearl: Phases of Clinical Trials

Phase I

(First in human)

Phase II

(First in patient)

Phase III

(Multi-site trial)

Phase IV

(Post-marketing)

10 – 100 

50 - 500 

500 - 3000

Large or according to study

Usually healthy volunteers

Patients with the target disease

Patients with the target disease

Real-world patients

Open-label study

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Usually the observational or open-label

Human pharmacology and safety: To determine safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetic parameters

Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging: To determine efficacy and dose-ranging

 

Therapeutic confirmation and comparison: Indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. Monitoring of adverse reactions is done. 

Postmarketing surveillance: To monitor drug interactions, compliance and long-term or rare side effects

Extends from months to 1 year

1–2 years

Unending, after drug approval

Related Pearl: Randomized Controlled Trials

Randomized controlled trials are a type of experimental studies.

Types

  • Clinical trials
  • Preventive trials
  • Risk factor trials
  • Cessation experiments
  • Trial of etiological agents
  • Evaluation of health services

General Design of an RCT

Steps of an RCT

  • Drawing up a protocol
  • Selecting reference and experimental population
  • Randomization
  • Manipulation or intervention
  • Follow-up
  • Assessment of outcome.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is being evaluated for sudden onset of hypersecretory glaucoma, diarrhea, and cardiac failure. Further probing reveals that she had been purchasing groceries from a dealer who was recently arrested for food adulteration. What toxin is likely responsible for her presentation?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic dropsy. It is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test

Related Pearl: Food adulteration diseases

(Hepatotoxic)		 Endemic ascites

questions.text: A teenage boy presents with the following finding. He says that many of his family members also have the same complaint. Which of the following is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Fluoride excess is responsible for dental fluorosis, which presents as the mottling of teeth shown in the image.

Fluorosis is caused by excess fluoride in drinking water. It causes dental and skeletal fluorosis. It can also cause osteosclerosis. Accepted levels of fluoride in drinking water in India are 0.5- 0.8 mg/L. Fluorine is an essential element for the normal mineralization of bones and the formation of dental enamel. The two principal sources of fluorine are drinking water and foods such as sea fish and cheese.

Other options:

Option B: Fluoride deficiency leads to dental caries.

Option C: Zinc excess can result in reduced copper absorption, gastritis, fever, nausea, and vomiting. Occupational zinc exposure in excess can lead to pulmonary fibrosis.

Option D: Zinc deficiency causes growth failure and delayed wound healing. It is also associated with alopecia, dermatitis, and diarrhea.

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters:

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU (nephelometric turbidity units) for household drinking water. 

It describes the cloudiness of water.

  • >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye.
  • <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU (true color units).  >15 TCU is detectable by the naked eye. 

Taste, odor and temperature

 No health based guideline values It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. High water temperature may enhance growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters:

  Guideline values
Ammonia

No health based guideline value.

Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium up to 0.9 mg/l
Arsenic

up to 0.01 mg/l

Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride

250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears.

Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/l. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper

up to 2 mg/l.

Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects.
Fluoride

up to 1.5 mg/l. Above this, there is risk of dental and skeletal fluorosis.

Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide

Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre.

A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent methemoglobinemia in bottle-fed infants and general population.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5.
Lead

up to 0.01 mg/l

The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury

0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury

It is nephrotoxic
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH)

Benzo(a)pyrene up to 0.0007 mg/l

They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give an unacceptable taste.
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable.

TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators:

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci: Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens: They are spore-forming organisms that are resistant to many disinfection methods. They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination. Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts measure a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidence of fecal contamination of water. 

IV) Radiological aspects:

  • The proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity, it is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: A researcher wants to combine twenty different clinical trials to assess the effect of a drug used for Alzheimer's disease. Which of the following best explains the type of study conducted?
questions.solution:
The type of study described here is a meta-analysis that involves combining results from multiple studies on a given topic.

Meta-analysis is the quantitative analysis of the results obtained from a systematic review. A systematic review uses certain inclusion and exclusion criteria to objectively review multiple studies. In the hierarchy of evidence, meta-analysis along with systematic reviews are grouped in evidence synthesis which is considered the best evidence. By combining the results of multiple studies, the power of analysis and generalizability is increased.

Other options

Option A - A cohort study is a type of analytical study that is done to support or refute an association between a suspected cause and disease. It can be prospective, retrospective, or a combination of the two. The cohorts are selected prior to the appearance of the disease being studied in prospective studies. In retrospective studies, the outcome has already occurred before the start of the study.

Option B - A case-control study is another type of analytical study. It is often called retrospective studies. It is a common method used to test causal hypothesis initially. It proceeds from effect to cause. Both the exposure and outcome have already occurred before the start of the study. It has a control and comparison group.

Option D - A randomized control trial (RCT) is used to evaluate methods of treatment and prevention by scientific techniques. By randomization, the participants are divided into two groups - study and control. The former group receives the procedure or intervention while the latter does. This helps to eliminate bias and ensures comparability. 

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: During your rural posting, you are asked to educate a small, uneducated village about the importance of routine antenatal care for pregnant mothers. You want to deliver some statistical data to emphasize its importance. Which of the following is the best method to do so?
questions.solution:
A pictogram is the best method of presenting data to people who cannot understand orthodox charts/ uneducated populations. 

In this method, small pictures or symbols are used to present the data. Fractions of the picture can be used to represent numbers smaller than the value of a whole symbol. Basically, pictograms are a form of bar charts.

The following image shows an example of a pictogram.

Statistical data after collection must be arranged in such a manner so as to bring out the relevant points clearly. Various methods to depict the statistical data include tables, charts, diagrams, graphs, and pictures.

Other options:

Option B: Line diagrams can be used to show the trend of events in a given period of time. 

Option C: A histogram is a pictorial diagram of a frequency distribution that consists of a series of blocks. The frequencies are given along the vertical axis and class intervals on the horizontal axis. The area of each block obtained is proportional to frequency. 

Option D: Frequency polygon is another method to diagrammatically represent frequency distribution. It is obtained by joining the midpoints of the histogram blocks.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: An annual symposium on diabetes mellitus is being conducted by a medical college. The event would most likely comprise of _______.

choices.text: A series of speeches on the topic with the chairman summarizing at the end
A series of meetings with emphasis on individual work within a group
6-12 people seated in a circle interacting with each other
4-8 qualified persons  discussing the topic in front of an audience

questions.solution:
A symposium comprises of a series of speeches on the topic with the chairman summarizing at the end.

A symposium is a series of speeches on a selected subject by experts. Each expert presents an aspect of the subject briefly, after which the audience is allowed to ask questions.There is no discussion among symposium members. The chairman makes a comprehensive summary at the end of the session.

Other options:

Option B - A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within a group, with the use of external consultants or experts. It can be divided into small groups each with a chairman and recorder. Each individual solves a part of the problem and leaves the workshop with a plan of action.

Option C - A group discussion is described as 6-12 people seated in a circle interacting with each other in a face-to-face manner. Health interventions that involve long-term compliance such as cessation of smoking, obesity reduction; group discussions are considered valuable. There should be a leader to start the subject and to ensure equal participation, preventing side conversations and summarize the subject in the end. A recorder of the discussion is desirable.

Option D - Panel discussions take place with 4-8 qualified persons who sit together and discuss a topic in front of an audience. It has a chairman, moderator, and 4-8 speakers. There is no specific agenda or set speeches. The audience is also invited to take part after the main discussion.

Related Pearl: Principles of Health Education

(Mnemonic: PLS, Good Friend, CLICK MoRe!)

  • Participation
  • Learning by doing
  • Setting an example
  • Good human relations
  • Feedback
  • Credibility
  • Leaders
  • Interest
  • Comprehension
  • Known to unknown
  • Motivation
  • Reinforcement

Related Pearl: Health Education vs. Propaganda

  Health education  Health propaganda
Knowledge Actively acquired Instilled in the mind
Skills Actively acquired Instilled
Primitive desires Disciplined Aroused
Action Reflective behaviour; trained to use judgement before acting Reflexive behaviour;Aims at impulsive action 
Emotion  Does not appeal to emotion but appeals to reason Appeals to emotion
Behaviour Process is behaviour centered  Process is information centered

questions.text: An epidemic of cholera has broken out and public health workers are taking rigorous measures to control the infection. Which of the following methods is preferred to disinfect small household wells in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The double pot method is preferred for disinfecting small wells as an emergency measure. This is because a constant dose of chlorine is desirable at the time of emergencies like a cholera epidemic.

Using bleaching powder is the most effective and cheapest method of disinfecting wells. The double pot method has an inner and outer pot, each with a hole in it. The inner pot has it in the upper portion and the outer pot it is placed 4 centimeters above the bottom. The hole in the outer pot is covered with polyethylene foil. The inner pot is filled up to 3 centimeters below the hole with a mixture of bleaching powder and coarse sand. It is then placed in the outer pot. The double pot system is then lowered into a well and immersed at least 1 meter below the water level. It can work satisfactorily for 2 – 3 weeks in small wells containing about 4500 liters of water.

Other options:

Option A: Horrock's apparatus is used to estimate the dose of bleaching powder needed for the disinfection of water. 

Option C: High-test hypochlorite also known as perchloron has 60-70% of available chlorine. It is more stable than bleaching powder and deteriorates less on storage. It is carried out for household purification of water.

Option D: Multi-stage reverse osmosis method is used for household purification of water. It makes water both chemically and microbiologically potable. It has a clarity cartridge and reverse osmosis cartridge.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient with increased blood pressure has come to the outpatient department. He asks about lifestyle modifications and a DASH diet was suggested. How much does the systolic blood pressure drop by adopting the DASH diet?

DASH: Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension
questions.solution:
The systolic blood pressure drops by 8-14 mmHg by adopting the DASH diet.

DASH is a diet plan which involves consuming a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced fat content. 

Lifestyle modifications to manage hypertension and the reduction in blood pressure are shown below.

Modification Impact on SBP
Weight reduction to maintain a normal body mass index 5–20 mmHg per 10kg weight loss
DASH diet 8–14 mmHg
Sodium intake reduction (< 6 grams of sodium chloride) 2–8 mmHg
Physical activity: 30 minutes of a brisk walk per day  4–9 mmHg

Hypertension is a non-communicable chronic condition that is a risk factor for coronary heart disease, stroke, and other vascular complications. It is known to be an iceberg disease and the rule of halves is applied. It states that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population are aware of the condition. Only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

Hypertension is a preventable disease. There are two approaches:

  • Primary prevention - includes measures that are taken to reduce the incidence by reducing the risk of onset. Population strategies are dietary modification, weight reduction, and exercise. A high-risk strategy prevents the shooting of blood pressure which might need institutional treatment.
  • Secondary prevention - includes the detection and usage of antihypertensives in affected individuals. 

Related Pearl: European society of cardiology guidelines for treatment of hypertension

questions.text: An infant was brought to the outpatient department with fever and rash as shown below for the past 2 days. The rash was pleomorphic and first appeared on the trunk.  What is the secondary attack rate of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a pleomorphic rash are suggestive of chickenpox or varicella infection. The secondary attack rate of varicella infection is approximately 85 % with a range of 61-100%. 

The secondary attack rate is defined as the probability that disease occurs among susceptible persons following exposure to an infectious person within the range of the incubation period.

Secondary attack rate (SAR) = (Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of susceptible close contacts). The secondary attack rate measures the communicability of the disease. 

Varicella or chickenpox is a highly infectious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus. The mode of transmission from person to person is by droplet infection or by droplet nuclei. This virus can cross the placental barrier and cause congenital varicella.

The incubation period is usually 14 -16 days. The clinical course can be divided into 2 stages. The pre-eruptive stage is marked by sudden onset of mild to moderate fever, back pain, shivering, and malaise. The eruptive stage is characterized by a rash that appears on the day of fever. They first appear on the trunk and then on the face, arms and legs. It advances quickly through all stages of macule, papule, vesicle, and scab. Rash exhibits a characteristic feature called pleomorphism because all the above stages of rash may be seen simultaneously at one time. 

Most cases of Chickenpox are mild and self-limiting. Oral acyclovir 800 mg five times daily or valacyclovir 1 gm three times daily or famciclovir 250 mg three times daily for 5 - 7 days is used for the treatment of acute infection. 

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

Related Pearl: Secondary attack rate of viral infections

Viral infection  Secondary attack rate 
Chickenpox ≈85% (61%–100%)
Measles ≥90%
Mumps 86%
Rubella 90%
Erythema infectiosum 10-60%
Infectious mononucleosis 10-20%

questions.text: The non-communicable disease (NCD)  clinic at the district hospital screens people above the age of 50 years with positive family history for diabetes.  What type of screening is this?
questions.solution:
The non-communicable disease/ NCD clinic at the district hospital screening people above the age of 50 years for diabetes is a type of high-risk screening. 

Screening is searching or testing for diseases or defects that are not evident in apparently healthy individuals. High-risk or selective screening is screening applied selectively to high-risk groups defined on the basis of epidemiological research. For example, screening the other members in families of patients with diabetes or hypertension that tend to aggregate in families. It is an effective and economical method of screening.  

Other options:

Option A: Mass screening is the screening of a population or a sub-group of the population for a disease irrespective of the particular risk an individual may run of contracting the disease in question. It is not a useful preventive measure unless there is a  suitable treatment that alters the duration or outcome of a disease.

Option B: Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests (instead of carrying out separate screening tests for a single disease) to a large number of people in the form of health questionnaires, clinical examinations, and investigations. It has not shown any benefit to the population in terms of mortality and morbidity reduction and has instead increased the cost of health services.

Option C: Prospective screening is screening people for the benefit of others. For example, screening immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis to protect the home population from the disease.

Note: Prescriptive screening is defined as the presumptive screening of patients for unrecognized diseases for their own benefit. It usually does not arise from a patient's request. Examples include screening for bacteriuria in pregnancy and screening for hemolytic disease in a neonate.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

questions.text: You were posted as a medical officer of a primary health center in a Kala-azar endemic area. There was a rise in the number of insects shown in the given image below. Identify the insect:
questions.solution:
The image given is that of a sandfly (Phlebotomus), which is the vector for Kala-azar.

Sandflies are generally small insects, light or dark brown in color. They are smaller than mosquitoes. Their body and wings are densely clothed with hair. Their wings are up-right and lanceolate in shape and their legs are longer compared with the size of the body. They hop about and do not fly much. The species of sandfly responsible for transmitting the disease kala-azar is Phlebotomus argentipes. 

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by various species of the genus Leishmania. It can present as visceral leishmaniasis, cutaneous leishmaniasis, ad mucosal leishmaniasis. Clinical features of the visceral form include moderate to high-grade fever with chills and rigors, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. 

The gold standard test for the diagnosis is the demonstration of amastigotes in the smears of tissue aspirates. Another commonly used test is the detection of antibodies to a recombinant antigen called rK39 by a rapid immunochromatographic test. In immunocompromised individuals, parasites can be isolated from the buffy coat. Amphotericin B is the first-line drug used in India. 

Other diseases transmitted by sandflies include sandfly fever and oriental sore.

For the reduction of sandflies, a  single application of DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) or lindane has been found effective. 

Other options:

Option A: Tsetse flies or glossinae are the blood-sucking flies that resemble the common houseflies. They are yellow or dark-brown in color. When folded, their wings overlap each other like the blade of a scissor. They have a non-retractile proboscis which is rigid and adapted for piercing the skin and sucking the blood. They are vectors for trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness and are only found in regions in Africa.

 

Option C- Rat flea is the vector for plague and typhus. They are wingless, their head is conical in shape, and is directly attached to the thorax without a neck. The head has piercing mouth parts that are conspicuous and project downward for sucking blood. They have 3 pairs of legs attached to the thorax. 

Option D: Black flies are small robust flies. They are black short stout legs, large broad wings, and a short proboscis to suck blood. They are the vectors of onchocerciasis in Africa, Mexico, Central, and South America.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.
