questions.text:
According to the National Immunization Schedule, what is the dose of vitamin A that should be administered with the first dose of the vaccine shown in the image?

IU- international units
questions.solution:
According to the national immunization schedule, 1 lakh IU of vitamin A should be given orally along with the first dose of the measles-rubella vaccine, which is shown in the image.

The first dose of the vaccine is given at 9 months of age. It can be given up to a maximum age of 5 years. It is given along with the measles vaccine as it enhances antibody production and confers sustained immunity against measles.

Vitamin A deficiency arises mostly due to its inadequate amounts in the diet. It can present as night blindness, conjunctival xerosis, Bitot's spots, and keratomalacia. At later stages, it can lead to xerophthalmia.

The image below shows Bitot's spots.

It also increases the risk of developing measles, diarrhea, and dysentery. Skin manifestations include xerosis, scaling, and dermomalacia. Phrynoderma may also be seen as keratotic follicular papules affecting the thighs and upper arms. It is shown in the image below.

In patients above the age of 1 year, vitamin A deficiency is treated with 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU by intramuscular route. It should be repeated the next day and four weeks later.

Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin, that plays an essential role in vision, reproduction, and maintenance of epithelial integrity. The various forms of vitamin A include retinol (storage form), retinal, retinoic acid, and beta-carotene. It is stored in the liver perisinusoidal stellate (Ito) cells as retinyl ester (retinol palmitate).

  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months

questions.text: A patient with Wilm's tumor undergoes renal transplantation. He is currently on corticosteroid therapy to prevent organ rejection. All of the following vaccinations could be given to this patient except?
questions.solution:
Intra-nasal/ nasal spray influenza vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, therefore it is contraindicated in this patient as he is immunosuppressed.

Live vaccines are prepared from live or wild attenuated organisms. They are repeatedly passed through tissue cultures or chick embryos in the laboratory. With this, they lose their ability to induce full-blown infection in an individual but retain their immunogenicity. It should not be administered to patients with immunodeficiency diseases, lymphoma, leukemia, or other malignancies. It is also not recommended in individuals on treatment with corticosteroids, antimetabolites, and alkylating agents. Unless the risk of infection exceeds the risk of harm, it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

Intramuscular influenza vaccine is an inactivated vaccine, which can be given in the immunocompromised.

Other options:

Option A: Diptheria-pertussis-tetanus (DPT) vaccine is a combination toxoid vaccine. The toxins produced by diphtheria and tetanus bacilli are detoxicated and used to prepare the vaccine. They are highly efficacious and safe. The killed whole organism is used for the pertussis component. 

Option B: Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine. It is produced by inserting a viral gene segment into a yeast cell. It does not contain viral DNA and will not produce an infection.

Option D: Inactivated polio vaccine is a killed vaccine. As the organism cannot grow in a vaccinated individual, it can be given to an immunodeficient individual.

questions.text: All of the following are duties of a male health worker except?
questions.solution:
All of the options are duties of male health workers except maintenance of eligible couple registers.

The maintenance of eligible couple registers comes under the purview of the female health workers. She is also expected to update it regularly.

Other options:

Option A: Male health workers are responsible for environmental sanitation. This includes chlorination of public water sources such as wells at regular intervals. 

Option B: Male health workers are expected to assist the accredited social health activist (ASHA) and other health volunteers in carrying out directly observed therapy, and short-course (DOTS) activities. He also motivates tuberculosis patients to adhere to regular treatment. 

Option D: The male health worker also has duties under the reproductive and child health program (RCH). This includes the distribution of conventional contraceptives to couples. He also helps prospective sterilization acceptors to undergo the procedure.

questions.text: To calculate the positive predictive value of a new screening test for breast carcinoma, what will you use for the denominator?
questions.solution:
The denominator for the calculation of the positive predictive value of a screening test is true positives + false positives.

Positive predictive value (PPV) of a test is TP/(TP + FP) x 100.

It indicates the probability that a person with a positive test actually has the disease. It is directly proportional to the prevalence of a disease.

Predictive value is affected by sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. However, it is affected the most by prevalence.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: You have conducted a case-control study for which you calculate the cross-product ratio to be 0.5. What would you infer from this?

choices.text: The factor can be considered as a risk factor
The factor cannot be considered either as a protective or a risk factor
The factor may be considered as a protective factor

questions.solution:
A cross-product ratio, also known as the odds ratio, of 0.5 indicates that exposure is associated with lower odds of outcome and may be a protective factor for the disease.

The odds ratio (OR) or cross-product ratio is derived from a case-control study. It is a key parameter used to assess the strength of association between the risk factor and outcome. It is a measure of effect. It means it measures the effect of exposure to a risk factor on the risk of developing a disease. Relative risk and attributable risk are the other measures of effect. 
 
OR < 1 indicates that exposure to the factor is associated with lower odds of the outcome. It implies that the factor may be considered a protective factor for the disease. 
 
Other options:
 
Option A: The prevalence cannot be calculated using the cross-product ratio. It is defined as the total number of cases (both old and new) in a population at a given point in time or over a period of time. It is given by the following formula:
Prevalence = Incidence x mean duration
 
Option B: OR > 1 indicates that exposure to the factor is associated with higher odds of the outcome. This means that the factor may be a risk factor for the disease. 
 
Option C: OR = 1 means that exposure does not affect the odds of the outcome. It indicates that a person with the disease is no more likely to have been exposed to the risk factor than is a person without the disease. It is not related to the disease and cannot be considered either as a protective or a risk factor. 

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: In the below-given project, which pathway if delayed causes a delay in the entire project?

choices.text: Start-->task A--> task D--> task E--> Finish
Start--> task B--> task C--> Finish

questions.solution:
Here the longest pathway is option C as it consists of (5+6)11 days, and so is the critical path.

The critical path is the longest path in the network analysis. Any delay in the critical path will delay the entire project. The critical path method is a type of network technique. 

The other common type of network technique is the program evaluation and review technique. An arrow diagram that depicts the logical sequence of events that must take place is constructed. The time duration that can be allotted to each activity is easily calculated. This helps to minimize any delays in the implementation of the plan.

Other options:

Option A: It is only 2 days, so it cannot be the critical pathway.

Option B: It adds up to 10 days and therefore is not the critical pathway.

Option D: Although task D is the longest activity, it is not the longest pathway.

Related Pearl: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

  • An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.
  • Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.
  • It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.

2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

  • The longest path of the network is called the critical path.
  • A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: A child was encouraged by his parents to follow a healthy lifestyle to prevent obesity. What level of prevention is adopted in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Primordial prevention is adopted in this scenario.

The emergence of risk factors for obesity is prevented by encouraging the child to follow a healthy lifestyle from an early age. This reduces the probability of developing obesity in the future.

Primordial prevention is the prevention of the emergence of risk factors in populations in which they have not yet appeared. Most adult health problems have their origins in childhood. Efforts are directed toward discouraging children from adopting harmful lifestyles. The main intervention in primordial prevention is by individual and mass education.

Other options:

Option A: Primary prevention is the action taken before the onset of the disease. This removes the possibility of the occurrence of a disease. Here, intervention is initiated in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease. It is accomplished by population strategy and high-risk strategy. Examples of primary prevention are immunization and sanitizing hands.

Option C: Secondary prevention is halting the progress of a disease at its incipient stage and preventing complications. Intervention is initiated in the early pathogenesis phase. Measures like early diagnosis and treatment are used to arrest the disease progression. Examples of secondary prevention are pap smear for early detection of cervical cancer and mammography to pick up breast cancer.

Option D: Tertiary prevention is the action taken to limit impairment and promote rehabilitation of patients in case of irreversible damage. Intervention is done in the late pathogenesis phase. An example is rehabilitation is providing walking aid for the crippled.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

questions.text: Program for improvement of quality of labor room comes under:
questions.solution:
The Laqshya initiative launched recently by the government of India refers to initiative for labor room quality improvement.

There is enough evidence to show that improving the quality of care in labor rooms, especially on the day of birth, is central to maternal and neonatal survival.

  • Laqshya is expected to improve the quality of care that is being provided to the pregnant mother in the labor room and maternity operation theatres, thereby preventing the undesirable adverse outcomes associated with childbirth.
  • This initiative will be implemented in government medical colleges (MCs) besides district hospitals (DHs), and high delivery load sub-district hospitals (SDHs) and community health centers (CHCs).
  • The initiative plans to conduct quality certification of labor rooms and also incentivize facilities achieving the targets outlined.
  • The goal of this initiative is to reduce preventable maternal and new-born mortality, morbidity, and stillbirths associated with the care around delivery in the labor room and maternity OT and ensure respectful maternity care.

questions.text:
Which of the following are considered as the best indicators of air pollution?
  1. Sulfur dioxide
  2. Lead
  3. Carbon monoxide
  4. Smoke
  5. Suspended particles
questions.solution:
The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles (1, 4, and 5). 

These indicators are monitored daily and their results are reported to a central agency.

Air pollution is the presence of gases and particulate matter in the atmosphere that affect human health and safety. It is also injurious to animals and vegetation. Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide
  • Smoke or soiling index
  • Grit and dust measurement (suspended particles)
  • Co-efficient of haze 
  • Air pollution index 

Air pollution in India is monitored by the national air quality monitoring program (NAMP). This program is sponsored by the central pollution control board (CPCB). 

Under the NAMP, four air pollutants are regularly monitored. They are sulfur dioxide (SO2), oxides of nitrogen such as NO2, respirable suspended particulate matter (RSPM/ PM10), and fine particulate matter (PM2.5). Monitoring of meteorological parameters like wind speed and direction, relative humidity, and temperature have also been included with the monitoring of air quality. This monitoring is carried out twice a week. 

The health effects of air pollution can be immediate or delayed. Immediate effects include acute bronchitis and suffocation. Delayed adverse effects are carcinoma of the lung and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

Air pollutants:

Pollutant Comments
Carbon monoxide Incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials like fuel combustion, vehicles, industries, etc.
Sulfur dioxide

Colorless gas
Sharp odor
Combustion of sulfur-containing fossil fuels, smelting of ores, etc
Main components of acid rain.
Lead Usually occupational and environmental sources
Carbon dioxide Increase in a global concentration above natural levels can increase temperature and affect climate adversely.
Hydrocarbons Cause photochemical smog
Cadmium From volcanic action, waste incineration, zinc production, smoking, etc
Hydrogen sulfide Waste-water treatment plants, wood pulp production, coke production, etc
Ozone Ground-level ozone is one of the main constituents of photochemical smog.
Oxides of nitrogen Most common form is nitric oxide
From coal burning, road traffic, and electricity generation
Affects the lungs adversely
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Incomplete burning of wood or coal, vehicle exhausts, smoking, etc
Carcinogenic and mutagenic
Particulate matter Mixture of solid and liquid, organic and inorganic matter
Major components are sulfates, nitrates, sodium chloride, mineral dust, black carbon, and water.
Common indoor air pollutants

From coal or fuel combustion

Include CO, PAHs, nitrogen and sulfur oxides, pesticides, and other biological pollutants


Radon, lead, asbestos are formed from construction materials, paints, and demolition

Effects of indoor air pollution:

  • Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI
  • Stroke
  • Ischemic heart disease
  • COPD
  • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
  • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight

Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide - one of the best indicator of air pollution
  • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter
  • Grit and dust measurement 
  • The co-efficient of haze - assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosols in the air
  • Air pollution index - measure of pollution severity
  • Suspended particle matter (SPM) 

In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text:
Match the following thermometers with their applications.
Type of thermometer Application
1. Dry bulb thermometer  A. The mean radiant temperature
2. Globe thermometer  B. The cooling capacity of the working environment
3. Wet globe thermometer  C. Low air velocities
4. Kata thermometer  D. The air temperature
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Type of thermometer Application
1. Dry bulb thermometer  D. The air temperature
2. Globe thermometer  A. The mean radiant temperature
3. Wet globe thermometer  B. The cooling capacity of the working environment
4. Kata thermometer  C. Low air velocities

A dry bulb thermometer is an ordinary thermometer used to measure the air temperature. It is mounted on the Stevenson screen for accurate readings.

A globe thermometer can be used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings. It is affected by both the air temperature and radiant heat.

A wet globe thermometer is used for measuring environmental heat. It exchanges heat with the surroundings by conduction, convection, evaporation, and radiation. The equilibrium temperature of the globe provides a comprehensive measure of the cooling capacity of the work environment.

A kata thermometer was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air. It was used to assess the indices of thermal comfort. Currently, it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities. 

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a sugar cane factory. You notice a patient with chronic cough and difficulty in breathing. Which of the following could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause in an individual working in a sugarcane factory presenting cough and difficulty in breathing is bagassosis.

Bagassosis is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of bagasse or sugarcane dust. A thermophilic actinomycete, Thermoactinomyces sacchari is the causative organism/ The symptoms are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, and fever. Initially, it can result in acute diffuse bronchiolitis. If left untreated it can progress to diffuse fibrosis, emphysema, and bronchiectasis.

The preventive measures which can be undertaken are:

  • Dust control: Measures to suppress dust such as wet process, enclosed apparatus, and exhaust ventilation can be undertaken.
  • Personal protection: Personal protective equipment such as masks or respirators with mechanical
    filters should be used regularly.
  • Medical control: Initial medical examinations and periodical medical check-ups of the workers are recommended.
  • Bagasse control: By keeping the moisture content above 20% and spraying the bagasse with 2% propionic acid (a fungicide) bagasse can be made safe for manufacturing use.

Other options:

Option C: A farmer's lung arises due to the inhalation of moldy hay or grain dust. It presents with common respiratory symptoms. Repeated attacks can lead to pulmonary fibrosis and cor pulmonale.

Option D: Byssinosis arises due to the inhalation of cotton fiber dust for prolonged periods. Patients present with cough and progressive dyspnea. Eventually, it can result in chronic bronchitis and emphysema.

questions.text: A newly pregnant woman from a rural area registered in the scheme shown below. Which of the following benefits would she receive under this scheme?

choices.text: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 homebased newborn care visits
Free checkup on 9th of every month

questions.solution:
The above image shows the logo of Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA). Under this scheme, all pregnant women will receive a free checkup on the 9th of every month.

PMSMA aims to improve the quality and coverage of antenatal care, diagnostics, and counseling services. This is undertaken as part of the reproductive maternal neonatal child and adolescent health (RMNCH+A) strategy. Under PMSMA, a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

After routine examination, pregnant women are categorized according to the risk factors, and different colored stickers are given as follows:

  • Green sticker: For women with no detected risk factor
  • Red sticker: For women with detected risk factor

Other options:

Option A: A cash incentive of 5000 rupees is provided to all pregnant women and lactating mothers under Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY) for the first living child of the family. This is subject to fulfillment of specific conditions.

Option B: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 home-based newborn care visits are provided under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative for women and newborns where assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare is provided free of cost.  It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths.

Option D: A cash incentive of 1400 rupees is provided to all pregnant women who underwent an institutional delivery in low-performing states under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY). This scheme is launched under NRHM (national rural health mission) to promote institutional delivery.

questions.text: You conduct a study to determine the association between computer use and visual impairment and get a correlation coefficient of +0.4. Which of the following scattergrams best represents your findings?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario having a correlation coefficient of +0.4 shows a positive weak correlation and the scattergram that best represents this finding is graph number 2.

Correlation is used to assess the strength and direction of the association between two variables (such as smoking and lung cancer). The correlation coefficient (denoted by r) is represented by a plus or minus sign, followed by a number (Example: -0.88). The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to +1.

The numerical indicates the strength of correlation:

  • Correlation coefficients greater than ± 0.5 are considered strong and are likely to establish (if positive correlation) or disprove (if negative correlation) the association between two factors.
  • Correlation coefficients between 0 and ± 0.5 are regarded as weak.

The sign indicates the direction of the correlation.

  • Plus sign (+) suggests that both the variables being studied are positively correlated. This means that the high value of one variable is associated with a high value in another. An example is an association between salt intake and blood pressure readings.
  • Minus sign (-) suggests that both the variables being studied are negatively correlated. A high value of one variable such as cigarette consumption is associated with a low value of another variable such as life expectancy.

The relationship between two correlated variables can be represented graphically in the form of a scattergram. Each point represents one observation including both the variables and so would be equal to the sample size.

The following image shows the scattergram plotted for different values of the correlation coefficient:

To combine correlations of two or more samples, averaging methods can be used. It is recommended only when several different samples are independently drawn from the same population and the interest is in aggregating those values.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: Which of the following recommendation was made by the Kartar Singh committee?

choices.text: Development of  primary health centers in 2 stages
Constitution of an All India Health Services

questions.solution:
Kartar Singh Committee recommended the feasibility of having multipurpose workers under health and family planning in India.

Kartar Singh Committee under the ministry of health and family planning recommended the following:

  • Structure for integrated services at the peripheral and supervisory levels
  • Feasibility of having multipurpose workers in the field and their training requirements 
  • Mobile service units for integrated medical, public health, and family planning

Other options:

Option A:  The development of primary health centers in 2 stages was recommended by the Bhore committee. Along with it the integration of preventive and curative services at all administrative levels was also recommended. The inclusion of 3 months of preventive and social medicine training in medical education was another suggestion put forward.

Option B: The development of a referral services complex was recommended by the Shrivastav Committee. This committee also recommended the establishment of a medical and health education commission.

Option D: Constitution of all India health services on the pattern of an Indian administrative service was recommended by the Mudaliar committee of 1962. It is also known as the health survey and planning committee. They found the services provided by the PHC are inadequate and advised strengthening of existing PHCs. It also recommended strengthening district hospitals with specialist services.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman whose mother is a known case of breast cancer undergoes a mammography every six months. The time advantage the woman achieves by doing so if diagnosed with breast cancer is represented by which of the following intervals in the given image?
questions.solution:
The advantage gained by screening is the lead time which is represented by the time period between 1 to 3.

Screening is the search for unrecognized diseases or defects in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applicable tests or procedures. It must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of the disease and the usual time of diagnosis (point 3 in the image). This ensures the success of any treatment in reversing the disease process. 

The time difference between the first possible point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis is called screening time which is represented by the time interval 1 to 2 in the above image. 

The final critical point (point 2 in the image) is the stage beyond which treatment would be unsuccessful or there would be permanent damage.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: An epidemiologist gives a lecture on pandemics. He gives influenza pandemics as an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Influenza pandemics are an example of a cyclical trend.

A cyclical trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. It occurs in cycles that are spread over short periods of time. This can be days, weeks, months, or even years.  Examples of the cyclic trend include influenza and rubella. Some non-infectious conditions can also display cyclical trends. An example of this is road traffic accidents occurring more frequently on the weekends. Knowledge of the cyclical pattern of diseases can be used to defend communities against the same.

Other options:

Option A: Seasonal trend is another type of period fluctuation which refers to seasonal variation of diseases. Examples of diseases that follow this trend include measles, malaria, and upper respiratory tract infections. It can be related to environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity. Some non-infectious conditions which follow this trend are sunstroke, hay fever, and snakebite. Some epidemiologists consider this a form of cyclic trend.

Option B: Secular or long-term trend signifies the changes seen in the occurrence of a disease over a long period of time. It implies a consistent change in a particular direction such as a progressive increase or decrease. Examples of conditions that follow this pattern are coronary heart disease and lung cancer which have shown a consistent upward trend. A decline in the occurrence of diseases such as tuberculosis and diphtheria has been noted in developed countries. 

Option C: Point-source epidemic is a type of common-source epidemic. In this type of epidemic, there are no secondary waves and the epidemic curve rises and falls rapidly. There is a clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time. All the cases develop within one incubation period of the specific disease.

questions.text: Which of the following does the label ‘X’ represent?
questions.solution:
Label ‘X’ represents perinatal mortality.

Perinatal mortality includes deaths in the late fetal period (stillbirth) and early neonatal period. This includes deaths from 28 weeks of gestation until 7 days of life.

The most common causes of perinatal mortality include birth asphyxia, low birth weight, and birth trauma.

In countries with well-kept records, the perinatal mortality rate (PMR) is given by the formula PMR = (late fetal deaths + early neonatal deaths) X 1000/ Live births + late fetal deaths in the same year. The babies chosen for perinatal statistics (late fetal deaths, live births, and early neonatal deaths) should be above 1000g at birth.

Other options:

Option A: Stillbirth is the death of a fetus weighing 1000g or more. This is equivalent to 28 weeks of gestation. 

Option B: Infant mortality is the death of an infant occurring within 1 year of life.

Option D: Early neonatal mortality is the death occurring between birth and 7 days of life.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: The fasting blood glucose levels of a  group of diabetics were found to be normally distributed with a mean of 110 mg /dL and a standard deviation of 10 mg /dL. From this data, it can be inferred that approximately 99% of diabetics will have their fasting blood glucose levels within the limits of ____.
questions.solution:
In this scenario with a mean blood sugar level of 110mg/dL and a standard deviation of 10mg/dL, 99% of diabetics will have their fasting blood glucose levels between 80-140mg/dL.

99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean. This proportion is true for every normal distribution. Thus, we have to add and subtract 30 (three standard deviations = 10 x 3) from the mean to arrive at the limits within which 99% of the population would have their blood sugar, i.e., mean ± 3 SD which will be 80 and 140 mg.

The standard deviation is the most frequently used measure of dispersion. Range and mean are the other measures. The shape of a frequency distribution is determined by the standard deviation and mean which in turn depends on the individual observations. A frequency distribution with a symmetrical, bell-shaped curve is known as a normal distribution. It is also known as Gaussian distribution.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a  type of mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
Perflation is not a type of mechanical ventilation. It is a type of natural ventilation.

Ventilation can be broadly classified as natural and mechanical:

Natural ventilation includes:

  • Perflation is the ventilation of a space achieved by allowing wind to blow through it and removing the obstacles for this to happen (e.g., opening windows and doors).
  • Aspiration occurs when there is an obstruction as wind bypasses it and creates a suction action.
  • Diffusion is the passage of air through small spaces or openings.
  • Cross-ventilation is when air is allowed a natural path through the space by providing openings at appropriate places, opposite each other.

The drawback of natural ventilation is that regulation of air quality is not possible.

Mechanical ventilation includes:

  • Exhaust ventilation utilizes exhaust fans placed high up near the roof on the external walls. A vacuum is created by which fresh air enters the ventilated space.
  • Plenum ventilation uses centrifugal fans to blow fresh air into the room and create a positive pressure, by which vitiated air is pushed out.
  • Balanced ventilation is the combination of both exhaust and plenum methods of ventilation.
  • Air conditioning can be done through mechanical ventilation. It is the simultaneous control of all or at least three factors that influence air quality in a confined room or space. These factors include temperature, humidity, air movement, distribution, dust, bacteria, odours and toxic gases.

questions.text: The quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is:
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, the quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is 0/100 mL.

Drinking water should not contain any pathogenic organisms or bacteria indicative of fecal contamination. The primary bacterial indicator used to assess this is the coliform group of organisms. This is because they are present abundantly in the human intestine and can be easily detected by culture methods. 

The presumptive coliform test can be done by the multiple tube method or membrane filtration technique. In the multiple tube method, the water to be tested is inoculated into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium. These tubes are then incubated for 48 hours and examined. The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to other organisms. The presumption that the reaction is due to coliform organisms has to be confirmed. McConkey's lactose bile salt broth with bromocresol purple 25 as an indicator is used as the media. The number of tubes with production of acid and gas can be assessed to estimate the most probable number of coliform organisms in 100 ml of water. Escherichia coli or thermotolerant coliform bacteria should not be detected in any 100 ml sample. 

In samples of chlorinated water, confirmation of the presumptive test is necessary. This is done by subculturing the positive tubes in two tubes of brilliant green bile broth. It is based on the fact that E.Coli is the only coliform that can produce gas from lactose at 44°C.

Supplementary indicator organisms include fecal streptococci and sulfite-reducing clostridia. 

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters:

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU (nephelometric turbidity units) for household drinking water. 

It describes the cloudiness of water.

  • >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye.
  • <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU (true color units).  >15 TCU is detectable by the naked eye. 

Taste, odor and temperature

 No health based guideline values It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. High water temperature may enhance growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters:

  Guideline values
Ammonia

No health based guideline value.

Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium up to 0.9 mg/l
Arsenic

up to 0.01 mg/l

Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride

250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears.

Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/l. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper

up to 2 mg/l.

Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects.
Fluoride

up to 1.5 mg/l. Above this, there is risk of dental and skeletal fluorosis.

Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide

Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre.

A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent methemoglobinemia in bottle-fed infants and general population.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5.
Lead

up to 0.01 mg/l

The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury

0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury

It is nephrotoxic
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH)

Benzo(a)pyrene up to 0.0007 mg/l

They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give an unacceptable taste.
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable.

TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators:

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci: Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens: They are spore-forming organisms that are resistant to many disinfection methods. They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination. Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts measure a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidence of fecal contamination of water. 

IV) Radiological aspects:

  • The proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity, it is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding the menstrual hygiene scheme?
  1. A pack of 6 sanitary pads is provided to adolescent girls
  2. The brand of sanitary pads sold is 'Today'
  3. These napkins are sold to adolescent girls at Re.1 for a pack of 6 napkins
  4. These napkins are sold by the accredited social health activist (ASHA)
  5. A payment of Rs.50 is given as an incentive to ASHA for conducting health issue meetings with adolescent girls every month.
questions.solution:
The correct statements regarding the menstrual hygiene scheme are 1, 4, and 5.

The scheme for the promotion of menstrual hygiene was launched by the ministry of health and family welfare under the adolescent reproductive sexual health (ARSH) program. It is targeted at adolescent girls between the age group of 10-19 in rural areas. 

The benefits received under this scheme are as follows:

  • A pack of 6 sanitary napkins is provided under the NRHM (national rural health mission) brand ‘Freedays’.
  • These napkins are sold to adolescent girls at Rs. 6 for a pack of 6 napkins by the accredited social health activist (ASHA).
  • A payment of Rs.50 is given as an incentive to ASHA for conducting health issue meetings with adolescent girls every month.

The above image shows a sanitary napkin under the brand name ‘Freedays’ which is distributed as part of the menstrual hygiene scheme.

The Objectives of this scheme are:

  • To increase awareness of menstrual Hygiene
  • To increase access to and use of high-quality sanitary pads among adolescent girls
  • To ensure safe disposal of sanitary napkins in an environment-friendly manner

questions.text:
A newborn baby presents to you with restlessness. On examination, the respiratory rate was 64/minute and there were no retractions. According to IMNCI, what would you do to manage this baby?

IMNCI: Integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness

choices.text: Admit to special newborn care unit

questions.solution:
Newborn babies presenting with increased respiratory rate of more than 60 per minute without retractions are classified as a priority. They need rapid assessment admission to special newborn care units (SNCU). 

According to the facility-based newborn care set up by the IMNCI (Integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness), SNCUs are set up in district hospitals and a few sub-district hospitals where there are more than 3000 deliveries per year. Neonates undergo quick screening for signs which help sort sick neonates according to emergency, priority, and non-urgent. Triage of sick newborn is done according to the signs observed as follows:

The IMNCI has set up SNCUs at district hospitals, stabilization units at community health centers, and newborn care corners at all facilities offering delivery facilities. This equips them to provide the requisite level of care. 

Other options:

Option A: Home-based newborn care aims to improve the newborn survival rate. It complements the strategy of institutional delivery to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality. An accredited social health activist (ASHA) is the primary service provider in home-based care.

Option C: Newborn stabilization unit (NBSU) is mandatory within or in close proximity to the maternity ward in all first referral units and community health centers. This is in addition to the newborn care corner. Babies with apnea, respiratory rate >70/minute with severe retractions or grunting, hypothermia, hyperthermia, central cyanosis, and shock are admitted to the NBSU. After initial stabilization, the baby is transferred to the SNCU.

Option D: Reassurance is not enough in this scenario.

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man visits your outpatient clinic for a routine follow-up. Which of the following protocols would you use to assess his health literacy?
questions.solution:
The SPEAK protocol is used to assess health literacy in the geriatric population in a clinical setting.

Health literacy is defined as the degree to which individuals have the capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information needed to make appropriate health decisions. The SPEAK protocol provides a simple framework that healthcare providers can use to assess literacy. SPEAK stands for:

  • S - Speech
  • P - Perception
  • E - Education
  • A - Access
  • K - Knowledge

Option A: The GATHER approach is mainly used for counseling (usually, family planning and reproductive counseling) to help people make decisions about health. It stands for:

  • G – Greet
  • A – Ask
  • T – Tell 
  • H – Help 
  • E – Explain 
  • R – Return 

Option C: The SPIKES protocol is used to convey distressing information and break bad news in an organized manner to patients and families. It stands for:

  • S - Setting
  • P - Perception
  • I - Invitation or information
  • K - Knowledge
  • E - Empathy
  • S - Summarizing or strategizing.

Option D: The S-BAR technique is used for prompt and appropriate communication among health care workers in hospital settings. It stands for:

  • S - Situation
  • B - Background
  • A - Assessment
  • R - Recommendation
